BOARD OF EDUCATION OF WASHINGTON COUNTY
Hagerstown, Maryland January 16, 1957
CLOSED-CIRCUIT TELEVISION
PROJECT NOTES
"Good morning members of the twelfth grade English classes of Hagerstown. This is a unique
and important occasion for all of us. You are participating in the first lesson to be telecast
in the Washington County Closed-Circuit Television Project. I am now looking straight into
your eyes and into the eyes of each of the 900 members of this class. Our class work is con¬
cerned primarily with the art of communication and we are using the most recent and spectac¬
ular development in the field of mass communication—television—to enable us to work to¬
gether. Our closed circuit is-— "
The speaker was Mr. Edward C. Kercheval, instructor in senior English. The time was 9:10
A. M., September 11, 1956, the second day of the 1956-57 school year. The first televised
lesson was on the circuit. The anxious faces of the group that had been working to initiate
the project began to relax. Plans were becoming a reality. At intervals during the day the
process was repeated with general science, geometry, and United States History. Newspaper
reporters in the schools recorded the reactions of pupils and teachers and agreed that here was
a great potential for the improvement of the educational program.
The events of this first day of telecasting were the results of many months of planning and
working together that had developed much enthusiasm in all who were working on the project.
This background included the preparation of the proposal by the Board of Education and staff
of what the project would include; c six-weeks summer workshop which developed the teach¬
ing procedures to be used; the installation of 12.5 miles of coaxial cable which connected the
schools participating in the first stage of the project; the development of a television center
to provide the facilities for preparing and transmitting the lessons; the orientation of all
teachers in the system to the use of television in the instructional program; and the utili¬
zation of the press, radio, demonstrations, and public meetings to acquaint the public with
the plans for the project.
The first lessons were televised from a makeshift studio with mobile equipment. Lack of equip¬
ment restricted the program to the four high school instructional areas for the first several
months of operation. Gradually permanent equipment replaced the mobile temporary equipment
and a television center was developed. By December 1956 the elementary school classes were
started and the full program was in operation.
Interest in and enthusiasm for the project have continued to mount. Teachers are suggesting
ways of improving the program and requesting opportunities to use television for supplementing
regular class instruction. The project has awakened a general interest in the instructional
process throughout the entire system. It has set off a chain reaction that is stimulating the
professional growth of teachers. The television project has been a means for developing
interest in the total educational program.
